data: Refer to Decision Support Tool: Perpheral Vascular Access

Indications:
To collect a blood sample or establish and maintain intravenous (IV) access or to manage hypovolemia

IV site should not be placed distal to or over the following areas: 
- Flexion (e.g. actecubital fossa, wrist)
- Infections (phlebitis, thrombosed veins, skin rashes)
- AV fistulas
- Circumferential burns
- Casted limbs
- Swollen or edematous areas
- Fontanelles, suture lines
-Feet after walking age and in children older than 10 years

In critical or emergency care situations, an intraosseous needle placement is performed by the
physician if venipuncture is not successful after 2 attempts

If venipuncture is not successful after 2 attempts. In critical or emergency care situations, an intraosseous needle placement is performed by the
provider
